Message.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Topic.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Message.Msg: "..Plenty of investors seem to know—and like—Amazon. About one-third of its shares are held by ordinary, noninstitutional investors.." Really? Only if Insiders are counted as part of the "ordinary, noninstitutional investors" ! The correct figure is, "ordinary investors" own about 13.8% i.e. 62 million shares which is less than what Bezos alone owns (88 million). http://eresearch.fidelity.com/eresearch/evaluate/fundamentals/ownership.jhtml?stockspage=ownership&symbols=amzn

Topic.Title: AMZN taking beatings like a red-headed step child.

Message.Msg: I am really helped and greatful to u for giving such a great information.

Topic.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Message.Msg: This article pretty much echos my sentiment regarding AMZN valuation. I can't buy into some of the short hyperbole on this board about how Amazon's business model is bust and how management is clueless and making one mistake after another. For all I (and anyone else who doesn't manage a multibillion dollar retail/internet business) know, Jeff Bezos may be making exactly the right decisions for Amazon's future. To me the best short argument is that there are way too many unknowns, particularly in the fast-moving, ever-changing landscape that Amazon operates, to be paying the kind of multiple of earnings (current, future, net, or operating) commanded by AMZN at the moment. Probably their margins will improve but its not guaranteed by a long shot. Jeff Bezos and Amazon management are neither idiots nor infallible geniuses. They are human and I believe many investors are betting that they can do no wrong.

Topic.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Topic.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Message.Msg: Interesting link/ breakdown of holders. Institutions unloaded 11M shares last Q and another 3M this Q, yet the share price is near all time highs. How does that work, when the institutional investors sell 14 million shares more than they buy and the share price moves higher?
